etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in American Journal of Science. From scientific Latin Hipparion, genus name from Hellenistic Greek ἱππάριον pony, already in ancient Greek in sense ‘wretched horse’ (as a term of contempt) from ἵππος horse + -άριον, extended form of -ιον, diminutive suffix

definitions: Any of the small three-toed equids of the extinct genus Hipparion, known from fossils found in Miocene to Pleistocene deposits. Also (in form Hipparion): the genus itself.
